key_points: Facebook announced plans to discontinue its facial recognition software, which could automatically identify people in photos and videos.
The company, now named Meta, also intends to delete the data associated with over a billion people's faces.
This decision follows scrutiny over the potential real-world harms of Facebook's platforms, highlighted by a whistleblower's leak.
Facebook's AI vice president, Jerome Pesenti, stated the company is reevaluating the use of facial recognition technology amid societal concerns.
Meta may still use facial recognition technology in future products, considering its benefits for identity verification and fraud prevention.
Critics, including law and computer science professor Woodrow Hartzog, view the decision as a victory for privacy advocacy.
Over 643 million people had opted into Facebook's facial-recognition feature, which facilitated user engagement.
Concerns about facial recognition include its accuracy and racial bias, with some cases leading to wrongful arrests.
Facebook's move could affect other companies and industries exploring facial recognition technology.
The company will continue to work on facial recognition technology, potentially integrating it into other products or services.
spokespersons: Jerome Pesenti (Vice President, Artificial Intelligence at Facebook)
Woodrow Hartzog (Professor, Law and Computer Science at Northeastern University)
Caitlin Seeley George (Campaign Director, Fight for the Future)
